subject: linear_algebra
title: Finding Eigenvectors: Null Space and Geometric Multiplicity
contentHtml:
Eigenvectors are crucial in linear algebra, as they help us understand how matrices transform vectors.

To find an eigenvector of a square matrix A corresponding to an eigenvalue λ, we need to solve the equation (A - λI)v = 0, where I is the identity matrix. This equation represents the null space of (A - λI), which contains all possible eigenvectors.
name: Eigenvector Equation" },
intuition: Think of the null space as a set of vectors that remain unchanged when transformed by A, except for scaling. Eigenvectors are special cases where the transformation is just a scalar multiplication.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, eigenvectors help in dimensionality reduction and feature extraction.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse eigenvectors with null vectors; they're not the same thing.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Finding Eigenvectors
contentHtml:
Finding eigenvectors is a crucial step in understanding the behavior of linear transformations. In essence, we're searching for non-zero vectors that, when transformed by the matrix A, get scaled by some factor λ.

Geometrically, this means finding directions in which the transformation stretches or shrinks the original vector.
name: Eigenvector Equation
intuition: Think of eigenvectors as special directions in which the transformation acts. By finding these directions, we can better understand how the transformation changes the original vector.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, eigenvectors are used to reduce dimensionality and identify patterns in data

subject: linear_algebra
title: Finding Eigenvectors: Null Space of (A - λI)
contentHtml:
Eigenvectors are vectors that, when transformed by a linear transformation A, scale up or down but do not change direction.

To find an eigenvector, we need to find the non-zero vector v such that (A - λI)v = 0. This is equivalent to finding the null space of (A - λI).
name: Eigenvector Equation" },
intuition: Think of eigenvectors as the directions in which a linear transformation stretches or shrinks. The null space of (A - λI) tells us where these directions are.
realWorldApplications: Principal component analysis (PCA) in machine learning uses eigenvectors to find the most important features
commonMistakes: Failing to recognize that eigenvectors can be scaled by any non-zero constant

problem.statementHtml: Find an eigenvector of the matrix A corresponding to eigenvalue λ.
hints: Start by computing the null space of (A - λI)
The eigenspace is a subspace of the null space, so find its basis
problem.solutionHtml:
To find an eigenvector, we need to find a non-zero vector v such that (A - λI)v = 0. We can compute the null space of this matrix using Gaussian elimination or other methods.

The resulting basis for the null space will contain our eigenvector. Since we're looking for a non-zero vector, we'll take one of the vectors in the basis and normalize it to get our eigenvector.

commonMistakes: Forgetting that the eigenspace is a subspace of the null space

statementHtml: Find the eigenvectors of matrix A = <latex>\[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ -1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}\]</latex> by computing the null space of (A - λI).",
hints: Start by finding the characteristic polynomial and its roots.
Use the eigenvectors to find the corresponding eigenvalues.
The eigenspaces are spanned by the eigenvectors.
solutionHtml:
To find the eigenvectors, we first compute the characteristic polynomial:

\[\det(A - \lambda I) = \begin{vmatrix} 1-\lambda & 2 \\ -1 & 3-\lambda \end{vmatrix}\]

Expanding along the first row gives:

\[(1-\lambda)(3-\lambda)-(-1)(2) = (1-\lambda)(3-\lambda)+2\]

Solving for λ yields two eigenvalues: 1 and 4.

We can then compute the eigenvectors by solving the system:

\[(A - \lambda I)\mathbf{v} = \mathbf{0}\]

For λ = 1, we get:

\[\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 2 \\ -1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\]

Solving for v1 and v2 gives the eigenvector [1, -1]T.

statementHtml: Find the eigenvectors of a matrix A.

Use the fact that an eigenvector is in the null space of (A - λI).
Check if your candidate eigenvectors are linearly independent.
solutionHtml:
To find the eigenvectors, we need to solve the equation (A - λI)v = 0.

Let's say A has eigenvalue λ with corresponding eigenvector v. Then:

\[ (A - λI)v = 0 \]

We can rewrite this as:

\[ Av = λv \]

Solve for v, and normalize it to get the desired eigenvector.

problem.statementHtml: Find the eigenvectors of the matrix \[A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ -3 & -1 \end{bmatrix}\].
hints: Use the fact that eigenvectors are non-zero
problem.solutionHtml:
To find the eigenvectors of A, we first need to find its eigenvalues. Let λ be an eigenvalue of A.

  • Compute \[A - \lambda I = \begin{bmatrix} 2-\lambda & 1 \\ -3 & -1 -\lambda \end{bmatrix}\]. This matrix represents the null space of (A - λI).
  • Find the eigenvalues by solving \[\det(A - \lambda I) = 0\].
  • For each eigenvalue, find its corresponding eigenvector by solving \[(A-\lambda I)v=0\]. Normalize the eigenvectors to ensure they have length 1.
